. . . 
"Despite stressing that ACP cannot be blamed for the delays, he argued that the communication surrounding them, or rather what he claimed is a “lack of clear communication”, left many sceptical of when the commercial opening date will actually be.
According to Kristiansen, while some are guessing the commercial opening will be in August or September 2016, others think 2017 is more realistic.
. . . 
In Kristiansen’s opinion, large scale redeployment of 8,000 – 9,000 teu vessels or full neo-Panamax vessels to the canal will not happen before 2017.

The Canal Project Minister announced that the Canal expansion would be operational by April 1st, 2016. Yet it is important to consider that this construction project has not exactly been timely—in July 2012 it was announced that the expansion project had fallen six months behind schedule and was to open in April 2015 (the original scheduled opening date was October 2014).  By the time September 2014 rolled around, the canal was expected to opened, and I quote, “at the beginning of 2016.” Clearly the canal is not yet ready and we are well past the “beginning” of 2016. The President of Panama said that he anticipated the expansion of the canal to be complete around May. Therefore by observing past trends of consistent overconfidence of how long the project will take, we can safely assume that the Panama Cana will not be open to shipping before May.

The canal's expansion was 96% COMPLETE at the beginning of December 2015.  A successful test of locks was conducted on Feb.14 and, on Feb. 15, it was announced that a major crack which further threatened the delivery date, has been fixed.  A dispute between the project's administrator and the consortium of companies behind the expansion over costs has been blamed for much of the delays -- the project was originally set at $5.25 billion, but the builders successfully argued for an extra $3.2 billion, of which the Canal Authority has paid $250 million so far.  The group of companies behind the project  announced last month that a  dispute to get the Canal Authority to pay them $17.5 million dollars for over budgeting and delays during the national strike in 2014, has been resolved.   President Valera said in January that the Canal would be inaugurated "AROUND MAY."  With a year and half of delays, another push on that date would not be good for Valera's record.  He was elected for a term of five years.  The country's constitution prohibits him from running for a second consecutive term which takes the question of election year pressure out of the equation. "We ... Quarta said that the potential delay problem is not due to the cracks and water leaks recently detected in the walls of three of the new lock levels, for which the United Group for the Canal, or GUPC, has been blamed and which will be "completely repaired by next January." Quarta insisted that the problem now is the same that has existed throughout the project, the "excessive and inexplicable delay in all bureaucratic procedures, certifications and ... payments established by contract" by the ACP. Any payment authorizations must go through five people who delay indefinitely, he said, adding that this is "smothering" the project. The problem has worsened since the new Panamanian government of Juan Carlos Varela took office because, Quarta says, the ACP has launched an exhaustive review of activities and projects inherited from the previous government of Ricardo Martinelli. "After exchanging an endless number of questions and responses, we get to a hearing to deal with an (arbitration) claim ... the ACP presents new arguments ... forcing everything to be delayed," the GUPC chief said. Quarta also said that the ACP has frozen payments of $250 million to the GUPC while the arbitration claims are handled.

"Nonetheless, the ACP appears to have accepted GUPC’s diagnosis – and their questionable solution. Starting in January 2016, extra rebar rods will be inserted into the lock wall and fresh concrete injected into the crack. "Why is an apparent construction flaw being touted as a design problem? According to analysis by Eric Jackson, editor of The Panama News: "If it is properly diagnosed as a bad concrete pour and properly resolved by tearing out the faulty concrete and redoing the work, that would cause major new delays and probably bankrupt construction companies… Calling it a design flaw allows for a quicker, cheaper and shorter-lasting fix and for those responsible for the bad concrete to litigate with designers in an attempt to pass off some of the costs of their mistake to others. "Jackson speculates that the collapse of the heavily government-subsidised Spanish construction company Sacyr – one of GUPC’s members along with Italy’s Salini-Impregilo, Belgium’s Jan de Nul, and Panama’s Constructora Urbana – could bring down Spain’s fragile economy. ". . .  news of further flaws surfaced via a memo by a US-British-Dutch consulting firm working for GUPC. " . . .the APC has been reticent in divulging official information about the problems. . . .  On 18 November, it did release a . . .  Youtube video . . . ~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  My resident concrete expert tells me that the core sample shows improper vibration during the pour.  The only proper way to fix that would be to demolition and re-pouring.  The "waterfall" phenomena/cracks reveal a cold-joint problem.  Putting in rebar and filling the cracks with epoxy or grout would be an appropriate remedy for a bad cold joint; a better solution would be demolition and re-pouring. COMMENT:  My resident concrete expert/husband tells me that there may be insufficient rebar in the concrete, but that is not the cause of the leaks. Blaming poor design (insufficient rebar) is the kind of thing a contractor may do to shift blame off their workmanship, and onto engineers. This question doesn't hinge on who is at fault, but only how long it will take to fix any problems.  THAT question hinges on how the problems are defined and how comprehensive the necessary repairs are deemed to be. The cracks and leaks were noted 3 months ago.  It is telling that any work necessary to stop the leaks does not seem to have been defined or begun, yet.

WHOSE POST DESERVES MORE UPVOTES! http://gcaptain.com/a-concrete-sample-was-pulled-from-the-new-panama-canal-locks-and-it-does-not-look-good/#.VkuNO7erTRb WOW!  Terrific link!  Great photos.   "The core sample photo shows concrete inadequately and improperly vibrated.  The 'waterfall photos'  definitely look like there's a cold-joint problem", says my husband, Alaska's best retired carpenter.  "This occurs when the bottom layer gets too set before another layer is poured and the vibrator isn't inserted far enough into the layer below, vibrated long enough, and removed slowly enough for all the air to bubble up,  to allow for proper mixing/bonding of the layers.    Adding steel rebar after the pour (as it sounds like they're doing) will make the joint stronger, but won't do anything to fix the leaks. The leaks will only get worse.   If this was a Corps of Engineers job, the contractor would be forced to replace the concrete!" "No wonder the unions are demanding an independent external inspection report!" "If this was just a retaining wall holding back dirt, adding rebar properly grouted in could be a fix, but it would be very tough to permanently water-proof such a fix, so the proper fix in this situation is demo-ing.  Before demo-ing could begin, the backside would need to be de-watered somehow.  There's no knowing how long it would take to get it de-watered; if it's necessary to build a coffer dam, it could take weeks to assemble the proper equipment and materials." "Demo-ing, if there's no rebar in the existing concrete, might be fairly simple and straight-forward, taking days for crews like I used to work with.  The whole wall would need to go to avoid creating another cold joint. Then, rebar would need to be placed so that the new concrete is stronger and the locks would need to be ground free of existing concrete.  New forms would need to be built, and the concrete placed.  Depending on the size of the crew and if proper equipment is on hand for demo-ing, the demo-ing & re-pouring process would take a week at the very minimum.  Depending on the design of the mix, the concrete would take 14-28 days to come up to strength. "All together, we're talking months to properly fix cold joint and improper vibration problems."   So, the questions are:  
-will the inspection report white-wash the problems?  
-will they decide to let the problems "pass" and decide to do a lot of pumping?
-how will the administrators view the situation if a few ships go through but then the canal is closed for extensive repairs/upgrades? I'm going to go to 0 on this because 
-I hope that they'll do the right thing and do a comprehensive repair (demo & rebuild)
-even a patch-job will take time
-the unions may strike if the repairs aren't going to be properly done, which would cause a further delay.  Workers have more incentive to do it right than contractors do, because a demo & rebuild is more work.  More work = more wages for workers, while for contractors it's just delay and expense.

My personal experience with most projects is that their duration is underestimated, often by a huge amount.  There's an optimistic statement from 01 October
"The consortium said water was seeping through because of “insufficient steel reinforcement,” which had been subjected to extreme stress from testing, the Panama Canal Authority said in a statement......Despite the repairs, the international consortium had “verbally indicated” that it will still complete the project in April 2016, the authority said".
 http://www.ticotimes.net/2015/10/01/builders-vow-to-repair-leak-in-panama-canal The various links given in earlier comments have been very helpful.  Pictures of the leakage taken in August show a waterfall rather than the more typical dampness or seepage one normally expects. When such massive concrete is so porous, the only appropriate description would be "a major failure", given that the purpose was to hold back water.
http://gcaptain.com/a-concrete-sample-was-pulled-from-the-new-panama-canal-locks-and-it-does-not-look-good/#.VkwlKHYrLcv I've been involved with concrete repairs in building structures, but the scale of this project is so much bigger than anything I've done that I'm hesitant to speculate. However, when one needs to strengthen a structure by adding reinforcement the usual option is to do it externally, either with steel plates or other material such as carbon fiber. When there is insufficient steel reinforcement inside a massive, custom-designed concrete structure, adding the required steel in the right place is not easy.  Demolition and reconstruction would do the trick, but I doubt if either the builders or the canal authority will want to do that. Yet another option would be to leave the wall in place, and thicken it with a new wall capable of resisting water pressures on its own. This would also delay the project significantly. However, right now I can't think of any other option that would address both problems - missing reinforcement and poor concrete quality - with any surety. Comparing with leaking concrete roofs, the points of entry of water from above hardly ever correspond to where the leaks are observed below, so "patch" repairs rarely solve the problem. Thus, injecting all the visible cracks and points of leakage with special chemicals (which the contractors may try)  is unlikely to be 100% successful, even after several iterations of injection and re-filling/testing, and they would still have to add the extra steel. I was hoping to find a report in one of the technical journals e.g. Engineering News-Record or New Civil Engineer, but a search of their websites doesn't show anything more recent than an arbitration award in favor of the contractor early this year. At this time, and until we learn more details about the Construction Consortium's proposals to rectify this problem, I'm going to start by predicting they won't complete repairs before the closing date of this question. However, with the Nicaragua Canal in mind, the expansion could be "open to shipping" on the promised date even before rectification  e.g. by using a lot of pumps! My forecast is therefore based on usage of the Canal rather than the likelihood of timely repair. Hopefully, the question will be considered resolved after the passage of a large ship rather than just an announcement by the Authority that they are open. EDIT: It occurs to me that if one section has been under-designed with insufficient steel reinforcement, have they checked whether any of the others have the same shortcoming, even if there are no visible indications?
